sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using QR decomposition
message_1:
Solve the system of linear equations using QR decomposition.

2x + 3y - z = 10

x - y + 2z = -4

4x - y - z = 6
message_2:
To solve the system of linear equations using QR decomposition, we first need to write the system in matrix form Ax = b, where A is the matrix of coefficients, x is the column vector of variables, and b is the column vector of constants.

A = | 2  3 -1 |
    | 1 -1  2 |
    | 4 -1 -1 |

b = | 10 |
    | -4 |
    |  6 |

Now, we will perform QR decomposition on matrix A. QR decomposition is a method of decomposing a matrix A into an orthogonal matrix Q and an upper triangular matrix R such that A = QR.

Using the Gram-Schmidt process, we can find the orthogonal matrix Q and the upper triangular matrix R.

First, we find the orthogonal basis for the column space of A:

u1 = a1 = (2, 1, 4)
u2 = a2 - proj_u1(a2) = (3, -1, -1) - ((3, -1, -1) • (2, 1, 4)) / ||(2, 1, 4)||^2 * (2, 1, 4)
u2 = (3, -1, -1) - 5/21 * (2, 1, 4) = (9/7, -12/7, -19/7)
u3 = a3 - proj_u1(a3) - proj_u2(a3) = (-1, 2, -1) - ((-1, 2, -1) • (2, 1, 4)) / ||(2, 1, 4)||^2 * (2, 1, 4) - ((-1, 2, -1) • (9/7, -12/7, -19/7)) / ||(9/7, -12/7, -19/7)||^2 * (9/7, -12/7, -19/7)
u3 = (-1, 2, -1) - 1/21 * (2, 1, 4) - 2/7 * (9/7, -12/7, -19/7) = (-1/3, 2/3, 4/3)

Now, we normalize the orthogonal basis vectors to form the orthonormal basis:

q1 = u1 / ||u1|| = (2, 1, 4) / sqrt(21) = (2/sqrt(21), 1/sqrt(21), 4/sqrt(21))
q2 = u2 / ||u2|| = (9/7, -12/7, -19/7) / sqrt(190/49) = (3/sqrt(190), -4/sqrt(190), -19/sqrt(190))
q3 = u3 / ||u3|| = (-1/3, 2/3, 4/3) / sqrt(6) = (-1/sqrt(6), 2/sqrt(6), 4/sqrt(6))

Now, we can form the orthogonal matrix Q:

Q = |  2/sqrt(21)   3/sqrt(190)  -1/sqrt(6) |
    |  1/sqrt(21)  -4/sqrt(190)   2/sqrt(6) |
    |  4/sqrt(21) -19/sqrt(190)   4/sqrt(6) |

Next, we find the upper triangular matrix R:

R = Q^T * A

R = |  3*sqrt(7)   2*sqrt(190)  -sqrt(6) |
    |      0       7*sqrt(190)  2*sqrt(6) |
    |      0           0        3*sqrt(6) |

Now, we can solve the system Rx = Q^T * b:

Q^T * b = |  2/sqrt(21)   1/sqrt(21)   4/sqrt(21) |  | 10 |
          |  3/sqrt(190) -4/sqrt(190) -19/sqrt(190)|  | -4 |
          | -1/sqrt(6)    2/sqrt(6)    4/sqrt(6)  |  |  6 |

Q^T * b = |  6*sqrt(7) |
          | -2*sqrt(190)|
          |  3*sqrt(6)  |

Now, we can solve the system Rx = Q^T * b using back-substitution:

3*sqrt(6) * z = 3*sqrt(6) => z = 1
7*sqrt(190) * y + 2*sqrt(6) * z = -2*sqrt(190) => y = -1
3*sqrt(7) * x + 2*sqrt(190) * y - sqrt(6) * z = 6*sqrt(7) => x = 2

So, the solution to the system of linear equations is x = 2, y = -1, and z = 1.
